Award.AwardTitle: Classroom Implementation Indicators for K-12 Common Core State Standards in Mathematics (CCSSM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on indicators outlined in the National Research Council report Monitoring Progress Toward Successful K-12 STEM Education: Indicator 4, regarding instructional materials that embody the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM), and Indicator 5, classroom coverage of content and practices as specified in the CCSSM. This project seeks to clarify these ideas and develop mechanisms to measure both the alignment of instructional materials and classroom instruction with key elements of the CCSSM. The project will accomplish its work through three types of activities: 1) meetings convened with STEM educators to work towards developing a consensus around the identification of appropriate concepts and their operational definitions; 2) a thorough review, evaluation, and synthesis of the current evidence base for such indicators; and 3) the drafting of specific recommendations towards the implementation of the measurement of such indicators. This project builds on and extends the knowledge and expertise gained from previous NSF-funded projects including the Survey of Mathematics and Science Opportunities (SMSO) that resulted in the indicators and instrumentation used in the 1995 Third International Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS) and the Promoting Rigorous Outcomes in Mathematics/Science Education (PROMSE) MSP.

Recent work has highlighted ambiguity in teachers' understandings of the CCSSM mathematics practices along with some differences in interpretation among mathematics educators. Effort is needed to secure greater consensus on these fundamental definitions before reasonable operational definitions for any indicator may be developed. The discourse methodology developed in the SMSO work in which informed experts wrestle together with appropriate data to develop consensus will be employed in multiple meetings with appropriate mathematics educators to make progress towards these important fundamental and operational definitions. Similar meetings to review and evaluate the current database on instructional materials (textbooks) and teachers' classroom practices will be held in order to move towards a synthesis of the data and a consensus around which indicators may be developed. Finally, based on these two efforts, experts in indicator measurement and development will be brought together with mathematics educators to draft recommendations towards the creation and feasible measurement of such indicators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was in response to the congressional mandate to determine how to implement the education quality indicators that were identified in the National Research Council's (2013) report Monitoring Progress Toward Successful K-12 STEM Education: A Nation Advancing? More specifically, the project defined the concepts and methods that could yield multiple indicators for the reports Indicator Four, involving instructional materials "that embody the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM)," and Indicator Five, addressing "classroom coverage of content and practices" in the CCSSM (p. 2, NCR, 2013). Such indicators of the implementation of high quality college and career ready standards are of interest as these are thought to lead to better student outcomes. Knowing whether and how the standards are or are not being implemented is essential for policy decisions that evaluate and respond to various measures of student learning and achievement.

     This project developed multiple examples of possible indicators. These were conceived, defined and simulated using previously collected data.  These possible indicators were then subjected to a thorough critical analysis by an informed experts Advisory group consisting of mathematicians, mathematics educators, and education policy stakeholders. This review considered not only the importance and value of each indicator but issues related to the ease, cost, and reliability with which the raw data for each indicator could be obtained.

     An important recommendation from this process was that the mathematics topics and concepts that would be included in any data collection instruments and, thus, in any indicator report, must be phrased so as to be relevant not only to those states that have adopted the Common Core State Standards for mathematics but also to those that have adopted similar college and career ready standards. This is a major challenge because the language that faithfully reflects the focus and concepts of each of the grade-specific CCSSM standards or other non-CCSSM standards and yet is easily understood by the teachers and/or students who may respond to a questionnaire gathering information for a desired indicator is not immediately obvious in the standards themselves. Typically such standards are crafted using the precise language and definitions of mathematicians and mathematics educators; a preciseness that is at odds with the mundane and ordinary sense such vocabulary suggests to the typical student or teacher.

     Another important recommendation was to focus on a few grade-specific benchmarks rather than attempt to capture a sense of the extent to which every single standard had been addressed. The range of standards is too large at every grade level to expect any single teacher, for example to complete a questionnaire that included them all. Several Advisory Board members are currently working on separate projects to identify the key standards or topics from which other grade-relevant standards and topics flow. Building survey instruments on the results of this work would help to reduce the response burden of those teachers or students who would complete surveys and would also likely become important categories for the development and reporting of the desired indicator. Based on the independent work completed thus far, the initial recommendation of the project's Advisory Board was to explore the use of the topics of fractions, triangles, and multiplication for the development of indicators for upper elementary grades mathematics.

     Results of this project has the potential to inform the ongoing regular monitoring of the U.S. education system. To the extent that such monitoring can reflect the substance and focus of the standards designed to guide classroom instruction this can also help local districts and schools make desired and needed changes to improve students' learning.
